{{no footnotes|date=March 2016}} In [[mathematics]], '''tightness''' is a concept in [[measure theory]]. The intuitive idea is that a given collection of measures does not "escape to [[infinity]]."<!-- and beyond!-->
==Definitions==
Let <math>(X, T)</math> be a [[topological space]], and let <math>\Sigma</math> be a [[sigma algebra|σ-algebra]] on <math>X</math> that contains the topology <math>T</math>. (Thus, every [[open set|open subset]] of <math>X</math> is a [[measurable set]] and <math>\Sigma</math> is at least as fine as the [[Borel sigma algebra|Borel σ-algebra]] on <math>X</math>.) Let <math>M</math> be a collection of (possibly [[signed measure|signed]] or [[complex measure|complex]]) measures defined on <math>\Sigma</math>. The collection <math>M</math> is called '''tight''' (or sometimes '''uniformly tight''') if, for any <math>\varepsilon > 0</math>, there is a [[compact space|compact subset]] <math>K_{\varepsilon}</math> of <math>X</math> such that, for all measures <math>\mu \in M</math>,
:<math>|\mu| (X \setminus K_{\varepsilon}) < \varepsilon.</math>
where <math>|\mu|</math> is the [[total variation measure]] of <math>\mu</math>. Very often, the measures in question are [[probability measure]]s, so the last part can be written as
:<math>\mu (K_{\varepsilon}) > 1 - \varepsilon. \,</math>
If a tight collection <math>M</math> consists of a single measure <math>\mu</math>, then (depending upon the author) <math>\mu</math> may either be said to be a '''tight measure''' or to be an '''[[inner regular measure]]'''.
If <math>Y</math> is an <math>X</math>-valued [[random variable]] whose [[probability distribution]] on <math>X</math> is a tight measure then <math>Y</math> is said to be a '''separable random variable''' or a '''Radon random variable'''.
==Examples==
===Compact spaces===
If <math>X</math> is a [[metrisable]] [[compact space]], then every collection of (possibly complex) measures on <math>X</math> is tight. This is not necessarily so for non-metrisable compact spaces. If we take <math>[0,\omega_1]</math> with its [[order topology]], then there exists a measure <math>\mu</math> on it that is not inner regular. Therefore, the singleton <math>\{\mu\}</math> is not tight.
===Polish spaces===
If <math>X</math> is a compact [[Polish space]], then every probability measure on <math>X</math> is tight. Furthermore, by [[Prokhorov's theorem]], a collection of probability measures on <math>X</math> is tight if and only if it is [[Relatively compact subspace|precompact]] in the topology of [[Convergence of measures|weak convergence]].
===A collection of point masses===
Consider the [[real line]] <math>\mathbb{R}</math> with its usual Borel topology. Let <math>\delta_{x}</math> denote the [[Dirac measure]], a unit mass at the point <math>x</math> in <math>\mathbb{R}</math>. The collection
:<math>M_{1} := \{ \delta_{n} | n \in \mathbb{N} \}</math>
is not tight, since the compact subsets of <math>\mathbb{R}</math> are precisely the [[Closed set|closed]] and [[Bounded set|bounded]] subsets, and any such set, since it is bounded, has <math>\delta_{n}</math>-measure zero for large enough <math>n</math>. On the other hand, the collection
:<math>M_{2} := \{ \delta_{1 / n} | n \in \mathbb{N} \}</math>
is tight: the compact interval <math>[0, 1]</math> will work as <math>K_{\varepsilon}</math> for any <math>\varepsilon > 0</math>. In general, a collection of Dirac delta measures on <math>\mathbb{R}^{n}</math> is tight if, and only if, the collection of their [[support (measure theory)|supports]] is bounded.
===A collection of Gaussian measures===
Consider <math>n</math>-dimensional [[Euclidean space]] <math>\mathbb{R}^{n}</math> with its usual Borel topology and σ-algebra. Consider a collection of [[Gaussian measure]]s
:<math>\Gamma = \{ \gamma_{i} | i \in I \},</math>
where the measure <math>\gamma_{i}</math> has [[expected value]] ([[mean]]) <math>m_{i} \in \mathbb{R}^{n}</math> and [[covariance matrix]] <math>C_{i} \in \mathbb{R}^{n \times n}</math>. Then the collection <math>\Gamma</math> is tight if, and only if, the collections <math>\{ m_{i} | i \in I \} \subseteq \mathbb{R}^{n}</math> and <math>\{ C_{i} | i \in I \} \subseteq \mathbb{R}^{n \times n}</math> are both bounded.
==Tightness and convergence==
Tightness is often a necessary criterion for proving the [[weak convergence of measures|weak convergence]] of a sequence of probability measures, especially when the measure space has [[Infinity|infinite]] [[dimension]]. See
* [[Finite-dimensional distribution]] * [[Prokhorov's theorem]] * [[Lévy–Prokhorov metric]] * [[Weak convergence of measures]] * [[Classical Wiener space#Tightness in classical Wiener space|Tightness in classical Wiener space]] * [[Càdlàg#Tightness in Skorokhod space|Tightness in Skorokhod space]]
==Exponential tightness==
A strengthening of tightness is the concept of exponential tightness, which has applications in [[large deviations theory]]. A family of [[probability measure]]s <math>(\mu_{\delta})_{\delta > 0}</math> on a [[Hausdorff space|Hausdorff]] topological space <math>X</math> is said to be '''exponentially tight''' if, for any <math>\varepsilon > 0</math>, there is a compact subset <math>K_{\varepsilon}</math> of <math>X</math> such that
:<math>\limsup_{\delta \downarrow 0} \delta \log \mu_{\delta} (X \setminus K_{\varepsilon}) < - \varepsilon.</math>
==References==
* {{cite book | last=Billingsley | first=Patrick | title=Probability and Measure | publisher=John Wiley & Sons, Inc. | location=New York, NY | year=1995 | isbn=0-471-00710-2}} * {{cite book | last=Billingsley | first=Patrick | title=Convergence of Probability Measures | publisher=John Wiley & Sons, Inc. | location=New York, NY | year=1999 | isbn=0-471-19745-9}} * {{ cite book | last1 = Ledoux | first1 = Michel | last2 = Talagrand | first2 = Michel | author2-link = Michel Talagrand | title = Probability in Banach spaces | publisher = Springer-Verlag | location = Berlin | year = 1991 | pages = xii+480 | isbn = 3-540-52013-9 }} {{MathSciNet|id=1102015}} (See chapter 2)

{{Blacklisted-links|1= *https://web.archive.org/web/20150818113418/http://www.timecube.com/timecubeflierimg.gif *:''Triggered by \btimecube\.com\b on the local blacklist''|bot=Cyberbot II|invisible=true}} {{Use mdy dates|date=March 2015}} {{Infobox website |name = Time Cube |screenshot = Timegrab.png |caption = The layout and writing style of the Time Cube website |url = timecube.com until August 2015
Archived at archive.org/web{{cite web|url=https://archive.org/web/|title=Internet Archive: Wayback Machine|publisher=}} | alexa = 517,356 ({{as of|2014|4|1|alt=April 2014}}){{cite web|url= http://www.alexa.com/siteinfo/timecube.com |title= Timecube.com Site Info | publisher= [[Alexa Internet]] |accessdate= April 1, 2014 }} |commercial = No |type = [[Personal web page]] |language = English |author = Gene Ray}} '''Time Cube''' was a [[personal web page]], founded in 1997 by the [[self-proclaimed]] "wisest man on earth", the late Otis Eugene "Gene" Ray. It was a [[self-publishing | self-published]] outlet for Ray's [[theory of everything]], called "Time Cube", which claims that all modern sciences are participating in a [[conspiracy theory|worldwide conspiracy]] to teach lies, by omitting his theory's alleged [[truth]] that each day actually consists of four days. Alongside these statements, Ray described himself as a "godlike being with superior intelligence who has absolute evidence and proof" for his views. Ray asserted repeatedly and variously that "[[academia]]" had not taken Time Cube seriously. Otis Eugene Ray died at the age of 87, on March 18, 2015.{{cite web|url=https://www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=gr&GRid=178435720|title=Otis Eugene Ray (1927 - 2015) - Find A Grave Memorial}} Ray's website domain names expired in August 2015,{{cite news |last=Robertson |first=Adi |date=September 2, 2015 |title=Time Cube Is Gone |url=https://www.theverge.com/2015/9/2/9247913/time-cube-is-gone |dead-url=no |work=The Verge |publisher=Vox Media |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150912045309/http://www.theverge.com:80/2015/9/2/9247913/time-cube-is-gone |archive-date=September 12, 2015 |access-date=February 15, 2016}} and Time Cube was last archived by the [[Wayback Machine]] on January 12, 2016. (January 10–14){{cite web|url=https://web.archive.org/web/*/timecube.com|title=Internet Archive Wayback Machine|accessdate=2016-06-25|website=archive.org}} An accurate mirror of the site is currently being hosted and maintained as of 2018.[https://ti.mecu.be "Time Cube"], Professor Squid, 2018. Retrieved July 8, 2018. ==Content== ===Style=== The Time Cube website had no [[home page]] or separate sections. It consisted of a single web page that contained a vertical column of centered [[body text]] of various sizes and colors. Ray used cryptic language that included insults and ''[[Non sequitur (logic)|non-sequitur]]'' lines such as "Belly-Button Logic© Works. When Does Teenager Die? Adults Eat Teenagers Alive, No Record Of Their Death." The narrative weaved in and out of his metaphysical ideas with numerous unique digressions. In one paragraph he claimed that because his own wisdom "so antiquates known knowledge", a [[psychiatrist]] examining his behavior diagnosed him with [[schizophrenia]].https://web.archive.org/web/20080709075217/http://www.timecube.com/, "My wisdom so antiquates known knowledge, that a psychiatrist examining my behavior, eccentric by his academic single corner knowledge, knows no course other than to judge me schizoprenic." Some have claimed it is futile to analyze the text rationally, locate meaningful proofs in the text, or verify any evidence. ===Time Cube concept=== [[File:Time Cube.png|thumb|Diagram illustrating an aspect of the Time Cube theory which Ray describes as "LIFE ENCOMPASSES A 4-16 CUBE PRINCIPLE"]] Ray's [[Mental model|personal model of reality]], called "Time Cube", states that all of modern physics and education is wrong, and argues that, among many other things, [[Greenwich Mean Time|Greenwich Time]] is a global [[conspiracy theory|conspiracy]]. He utilizes various graphs (along with pictures of himself) that purport to show how each day is really four separate days—[[Sunrise|sunup]], [[Noon|midday]], [[Sunset|sundown]], and [[midnight]] (formerly morning, early afternoon, late afternoon, and evening)—occurring simultaneously.{{cite news |last=Duffy |first=Kate |date=September 19, 2002 |title=Truth Is Cubic? |url=http://www.sccs.swarthmore.edu/org/phoenix/2002/2002-09-19/living/12178.php |newspaper=The Phoenix |location=Swarthmore, Pennsylvania |publisher=Swarthmore College |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20021220092124/http://www.sccs.swarthmore.edu/org/phoenix/2002/2002-09-19/living/12178.php |archive-date=December 20, 2002 |access-date=July 25, 2010}} The following quotation from the website illustrates the recurring theme: {{quote|When the Sun shines upon Earth, 2 – major Time points are created on opposite sides of Earth – known as Midday and Midnight. Where the 2 major Time forces join, synergy creates 2 new minor Time points we recognize as Sunup and Sundown. The 4-[[equidistant]] Time points can be considered as Time Square imprinted upon the circle of Earth. In a single rotation of the Earth sphere, each Time corner point rotates through the other 3-corner Time points, thus creating 16 corners, 96 hours and 4-[[simultaneous]] 24-hour Days within a single rotation of Earth – equated to a Higher Order of Life Time Cube.}} Ray offered $1,000{{cite web|url=http://www.timecube.com/timecubeflierimg.gif |title=Timecube.com Picture |accessdate=September 14, 2014 |deadurl=unfit |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150818113418/http://www.timecube.com/timecubeflierimg.gif |archivedate=August 18, 2015 }} or $10,000 to anyone who could prove his views wrong. Mike Hartwell of ''[[The Maine Campus]]'' wrote that any attempt to claim the prize would require convincing Ray that his theory was invalid. The proof would need to be framed in terms of his own model, thus deviating from any form of modern science. "Even if you could pull that off", Harwell said, "Ray is probably broke". ==Reception== Ray spoke about Time Cube at the [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology]] in January 2002 as part of a student-organized extra-curricular event during the independent activities period.{{cite web |url=http://web.mit.edu/iap/www/iap02/searchiap/iap-4330.html |title=IAP 2002 Activity: Time Cube Lecture / Debate |accessdate=April 5, 2007}} He repeated his $10,000 offer for professors to disprove his notions at the event; none attempted it. [[John C. Dvorak]] wrote in ''[[PC Magazine]]'' that "Metasites that track crackpot sites often say this is the number one nutty site."{{cite web |last=Dvorak |first=John C. |author-link=John C. Dvorak |date=December 22, 2003 |title=Don't Call Them Crackpots |url=https://www.pcmag.com/article2/0,4149,1420072,00.asp |website=PC Magazine |access-date=August 20, 2018}} He also characterized the site's content as "endless blather". Asked by [[Martin Sargent]] in 2003 how it felt to be an [[Internet celebrity]], Ray stated that it was not a position he wanted, but something he felt he had to do as "no writer or speaker understands the Time Cube".{{cite episode |date=June 18, 2003 |series=[[Unscrewed with Martin Sargent]] |season=1 |number=15 |network=TechTV |quote=''Sargent:'' Gene, how do you feel about being an Internet celebrity? I mean, you're huge on the web. ''Ray:'' Well, it's not a position I wanted, it's something I had to do. I'm not a writer or speaker, but no writer or speaker understands the Time Cube.}} Ray also spoke about Time Cube at the [[Georgia Institute of Technology]] in April 2005, in a speech in which he attacked the instruction offered by academics.[https://smartech.gatech.edu/bitstream/1853/7877/3/focus-2005-04-22.pdf "Oddball Time Cube theorist piques interest, elicits mixed response"], by Joshua Cuneo, ''[[The Technique]]''. [[Georgia Institute of Technology]]. April 22, 2005. Retrieved July 25, 2010. A 2004 editorial in ''The Maine Campus'' student newspaper remarked upon what it called the site's "subtle little racist ideologies" which culminate in Ray describing [[racial integration]] as "destroying all of the races".{{Cite news|url=http://mainecampus.com/2004/09/24/timecubecom-where-reality-as-we-know-it-is-a-lie |title=Timecube.com: Where reality as we know it is a lie |last=Hartwell |first=Mark |date=September 24, 2004 |newspaper=The Maine Campus |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110430225718/http://mainecampus.com/2004/09/24/timecubecom-where-reality-as-we-know-it-is-a-lie/ |archive-date=April 30, 2011 |access-date=July 25, 2010 |deadurl=yes |df= }} In 2005, Brett Hanover made ''Above God'' (also the name of one of Ray's websites which criticized the idea that God exists),abovegod.com a short documentary film about Ray and Time Cube,[http://www.bretthanover.com/video.html ''Above God''], Brett Hanover official site. Retrieved July 25, 2010. ==Suicide of Richard Janczarski== Richard Janczarski, also known online as "Cubehead", was a self-professed disciple of Ray who styled himself the "second-wisest human".{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PL93505B8EF06578EB|title=Dr Gene Ray Time Cube Experience|publisher=Richard Janczarski}} From 2004, Janczarski created the Time Cube fansite Cubic Awareness Online, and an accompanying forum. In 2007, he travelled from his native [[Australia]] to [[Florida]] to meet Ray. The pair had several disagreements after going their separate ways.{{cite interview |last=Janczarski |first=Richard |interviewer=Charles Berman |title=The Bronze Age of Radio |url=https://yadi.sk/d/t8cdVYIpjMEPn |publisher=[[WHRW]] |location=[[New York City|New York]] |date=2007}} Ray denounced Janczarski on his website after the latter’s visit.
